body:
Hi **@wictorwilen**, I'm your friendly neighborhood Microsoft Pull Request Bot (You can call me MSBOT). Thanks for your contribution! You've already signed the contribution license agreement. Thanks!

The agreement was validated by Microsoft and real humans are currently evaluating your PR.

TTYL, MSBOT;
Thx Wictor, good edits.

I have tried to install the SharePoint generator both globally and locally, nothing, no joy...

the frustrating part is not having anything to look at, like where are the files installed by npm.

On the **_windows_** platform, after reading the @microsfotSharePoint installation log, I found the reason for the generator-sharepoint failure. there were several modules MISSING from the dependencies list. so I created a new install batch file with the following modules:

**_call npm uninstall -g chalk_**
**_call npm uninstall -g loadash_**
**_call npm uninstall -g tar-fs_**
**_call npm uninstall -g update-notifier_**
**_call npm uninstall -g yeoman-generator_**
**_call npm uninstall -g yosay_**
**_call npm uninstall -g yo_**
**_call npm uninstall -g gulp_**
**_call npm uninstall -g @microsoft/generator-sharepoint_**

**_call npm install -g chalk_**
**_call npm install -g loadash_**
**_call npm install -g tar-fs_**
**_call npm install -g update-notifier_**
**_call npm install -g yeoman-generator_**
**_call npm install -g yosay_**

**_call npm install -g yo_**
**_call npm install -g gulp_**

**_call npm install -g @microsoft/generator-sharepoint_**

and this made sure everything installs correctly and the SharePoint framework is ready for creating and testing the helloWorld webpart application.
issue is now closed LCR

The agreement was validated by Microsoft and real humans are currently evaluating your PR.

TTYL, MSBOT;
Closing this PR as I have updated the web part and created another pull request: https://github.com/SharePoint/sp-dev-fx-webparts/pull/15

Hi Vardhaman,
Great sample and good to get that shared. We would though have few asks for this based on updated contribution guidelines, which are unfortunately still in dev branch, so it's understandable that you did not see them. Here's the link for the file - https://github.com/SharePoint/sp-dev-fx-webparts/blob/dev/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md. This was not there in master branch, when you submitted your PR.

In short:
1. Folder name of the sample solution should contain the used JS library, like existing ones - like angular- or react-. If sample is not using any specific library, it should start with js- prefix
2. Submission should be targeted to dev branch - this is for engineering to do final checkup on things, before getting merged with master - this will happen gradually at least once a week

Hopefully fine with these. We are trying to ensure that we have structure cross the samples and to avoid future confusion cross samples from day one... or from day two, now that the guidance was not there when you submitted yours.

thx Roland, we would have one ask around this, which is the folder naming for the sample solution. We just updated our contribution guidance with details on this, so sorry for the additional ask, since that was missing when you submitted your sample - https://github.com/SharePoint/sp-dev-fx-webparts/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md. 

Key point to notice would be the folder naming. So we should use angular-, react- etc. in the name, so that sample is getting grouped with similar technologies in the folder. If you are not using any generic library, we would ask that folder name starts with js- prefix. So in this case folder name would be "js-powerbi-embedded".

This is really nice sample showing the integration and great to get it included. Hopefully folder rename works for you, but obviously can do that afterwards as well, if you are running out of time.
@VesaJuvonen No worries at all. I've renamed the folder to js-powerbi-embedded!
thx Roland, great stuff.
